ygData.subject: Re: ANN: SharpNEAT Release (31-May-2004)
ygData.msgSnippet: Very cool visualization interface!  I noticed a few minor things though: -I don t think the default value for connectness of the initial genome should be 0.2.

Very cool visualization interface!  I noticed a few minor things 
though:

-I don't think the default value for connectness of the initial 
genome should be 0.2.  The default should be 1 and people should be 
able to adjust it down from there.  I think most users would not 
know what the 0.2 is and not understand what affect it's having.

-I find I can't delete a network in the species visualization as it 
says I can.  The only species that I can get to disappear are dead 
ones, and not by clicking on them.

-Something went wrong with file loading in the pole balacing and 
prey capture simulators.  It seems you changed something about your 
file structure but didn't make the corresponding change in their 
loaders.

It's getting quite impressive.  Congratulations on really nice work!

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> At the usual URL http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/
> 
> Notes from the web site:
> 
> ------------------
> New network visualization windows in the main SharpNEAT 
executable. This 
> includes a best genome window and a window for monitoring the best 
> genomes from a selected range of species, you can also set this 
window 
> to monitor the best N species.
> 
> New network visualization tool (bin/NetworkViewer.exe). Currently 
this 
> loads and displays SharpNEAT network XML. There are plans turn 
this into 
> an editor and to support loading/saving of other network and 
genome file 
> formats
> 
> Important Notice. There currently exists a problem in the genome 
> crossover code that allows multiple connections to accrue between 
two 
> neurons, or between a single neuron in the case of recurrent 
> conenctions. This will have some detrimental effect on searches, 
> although how much of an effect is not known. This problem is being 
> worked on.
> ------------------
> 
> Regarding the last point, I was intending to resolve this problem 
today 
> but I'm still deciding on the best way to do this. I was going to 
try 
> and maintain a full history of all additions, which would solve 
the 
> problem and actually it sounds like a better strategy. 
Unfortunately if 
> I do it this way then the problem re-appears when you distribute a 
> search over multiple PCs - or at least the using the way I was 
thinking 
> of doing distribution anyhow.
